metadata.TITLE: Catch Up On The Latest News Clips - ITVX
metadata.DESC: Discover the latest and breaking news clips from ITV. ITVX - The UK's freshest streaming service.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: The latest ITV News headlines - as UN warns situation in Gaza getting 'even more hellish'
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: Watch a short summary of today's top stories from the ITV News team.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: UN warns "even more hellish" situation about to unfold in Gaza as Israel intensifies attacks
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: The World Health Organisation has said Palestinians have 'no safe zones' to flee to as Israeli airstrikes increase on Khan Younis, Gaza's second largest city.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Home Secretary signs new migration treaty with Rwanda - so what is in it?
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: James Cleverly has signed a new treaty which he believes addresses the legal concerns which caused the Supreme Court to block the original plan.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Junior doctors in England announce new strikes dates in December and January
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: The BMA has announced fresh strike dates in the lead up to Christmas, as well as their longest ever strike in NHS history in the New Year.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Man arrested on suspicion of attempted murder after woman stabbed in Aberfan
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: A 29-year-old woman was attacked in Aberfan on Tuesday morning and her injuries are not believed to be life-threatening.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Infected blood scandal: Families demand full compensation after MPs vote to speed up process
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: Around 3,000 people are thought to have died from infected blood, with the bill for compensation likely to amount to thousands of pounds.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Spice Girl Mel C and comedian Catherine Tate among celebrities settling hacking claims
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: The group had made complaints about information misuse and took legal action against News Group Newspapers, which also used to publish the News of the World.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: As Prince Harry takes his latest legal challenge to the High Court, what is it all about?
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: The Duke of Sussex is taking action against the Home Office over the decision to cut his personal security while visiting the UK.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Caught on camera: Explosion at house in Virginia sends fireball into the air
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: Police are investigating an explosion which destroyed a home after officers were called to reports of a man firing a flare gun, followed by a police siege.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: New Grand Theft Auto trailer leaked online but fans still face a lengthy wait to play
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: The trailer for the highly-anticipated sixth game appeared online hours before it was meant to be officially released and contains a female protagonist.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Floods subside in Brechin but anger remains as clean-up continues weeks later
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: Six weeks on from Storm Babet, the people of Brechin feel that more needs to be done to help with the clean-up and stop a repeat of the disastrous flooding.

heroAndLatestData.episodeTitle: Chilly with frost and fog: Watch the latest ITV Weather
heroAndLatestData.synopsis: Watch the latest UK forecast from the ITV Weather team.

clips.episodeTitle: Home Secretary signs new migration treaty with Rwanda - so what is in it?
clips.synopsis: James Cleverly has signed a new treaty which he believes addresses the legal concerns which caused the Supreme Court to block the original plan.

clips.episodeTitle: Junior doctors in England announce new strikes dates in December and January
clips.synopsis: The BMA has announced fresh strike dates in the lead up to Christmas, as well as their longest ever strike in NHS history in the New Year.

clips.episodeTitle: What are the big questions Boris Johnson is facing at the Covid Inquiry?
clips.synopsis: The former Prime Minister faces two days of examination, where his handling of the pandemic and the workings of his government will come under the spotlight.

clips.episodeTitle: Infected blood scandal: Families demand full compensation after MPs vote to speed up process
clips.synopsis: Around 3,000 people are thought to have died from infected blood, with the bill for compensation likely to amount to thousands of pounds.

clips.episodeTitle: Boris Johnson 'to admit mistakes in pandemic handling' at Covid Inquiry
clips.synopsis: According to The Times, the former prime minister will also argue that decisions he took ended up saving "tens if not hundreds of thousands of lives".

clips.episodeTitle: The Covid Inquiry: The key moments as Matt Hancock gave evidence
clips.synopsis: The former Health Secretary during the pandemic, Matt Hancock, faced questions at the Covid Inquiry after being criticised by several former colleagues.

clips.episodeTitle: Diplomatic fallout between UK and Greece continues in row over Elgin Marbles' return
clips.synopsis: Greece say it was disrespectful for the UK PM to opt out of the meeting, but Downing Street argue the Greek PM broke an agreement to not discuss the marbles.

clips.episodeTitle: Covid Inquiry: Michael Gove apologises to victims' families for 'mistakes'
clips.synopsis: Michael Gove, who was Minister for the Cabinet Office during the pandemic, acknowledged that the government had made mistakes.

clips.episodeTitle: Bank of England governor gives gloomy view of UK economy's potential
clips.synopsis: Andrew Bailey has suggested the growth potential was among the worst he'd seen in his lifetime, but Downing Street disagree and remain optimistic.

clips.episodeTitle: Covid Inquiry: Regional mayors hit out at lack of consultation on key decisions
clips.synopsis: Sadiq Khan says he was not invited to government meetings early in the pandemic and claims Boris Johnson didn't know other countries were imposing lockdowns.

clips.episodeTitle: Campaigners welcome plans for domestic killers to face tougher sentences
clips.synopsis: The minimum sentence could be raised for murderers who used a weapon already at the scene. Every year around 90 people are killed by a partner or ex-partner.

clips.episodeTitle: Consultants reach pay deal with the government but other health workers "appalled"
clips.synopsis: The British Medical Association said the offer constituted a 4.95% "investment in pay" on top of the 6% pay rise already awarded this year.

clips.episodeTitle: Labour attack Government's claims to have cut taxes in autumn statement
clips.synopsis: Labour say it has identified 12 'stealth taxes' set to total £810 per household, but the Treasury say personal taxes are lower than in any other G7 country.

clips.episodeTitle: UN warns "even more hellish" situation about to unfold in Gaza as Israel intensifies attacks
clips.synopsis: The World Health Organisation has said Palestinians have 'no safe zones' to flee to as Israeli airstrikes increase on Khan Younis, Gaza's second largest city.

clips.episodeTitle: Home Secretary signs new migration treaty with Rwanda - so what is in it?
clips.synopsis: James Cleverly has signed a new treaty which he believes addresses the legal concerns which caused the Supreme Court to block the original plan.

clips.episodeTitle: Senior U.S. diplomat accused of spying for Cuba since at least 1981
clips.synopsis: Manuel Rocha rose to become the American Ambassador to Bolivia. He was approached by an undercover FBI officer, where he allegedly boasted of being a Cuban spy.

clips.episodeTitle: Palestinians running out of places to flee as Israel expands ground operation
clips.synopsis: Israel had ordered civilians in northern Gaza to head south in the early days of the war, but the offensive has now expanded with heavy bombardment reported.

clips.episodeTitle: Pentagon says U.S. warship and other vessels attacked in the Red Sea
clips.synopsis: U.S. officials haven't yet said where they think the attack came from, but Yemen's Houthi rebels have recently been launching strikes on vessels in the Red Sea,

clips.episodeTitle: One dead and two injured, including British man, following Paris 'terror attack'
clips.synopsis: A German man has been killed and a British man among two people injured, after a knife and hammer attack near the Eiffel Tower in central Paris on Saturday.

clips.episodeTitle: Hundreds killed in 24 hours as Israel expands offensive in southern Gaza
clips.synopsis: Israel's military has ordered more areas around Khan Younis to evacuate as it shifts its offensive to southern Gaza where it says many Hamas leaders are hiding.

clips.episodeTitle: Heavy snowfall throws parts of Europe into chaos as warnings issued
clips.synopsis: Avalanche warnings have been issued in western Austria where around 50cm of snow fell. In the Czech capital Prague, a state of emergency was declared.

clips.episodeTitle: Hamas says Israeli strikes have killed over 175 people in Gaza since ceasefire ended
clips.synopsis: Israel warned civilians in the southern part of Gaza to evacuate after the deadline for another ceasefire extension passed.

clips.episodeTitle: Devastating impact on communities as glaciers melt in Pakistan
clips.synopsis: The country is hoping COP28 will ratify a loss and damage fund to help developing nations cover the costs of the climate change crises they are facing.

clips.episodeTitle: COP28: Guterres warns 'we are living through climate collapse in real time'
clips.synopsis: António Guterres delivered a stark opening address as world leaders gathered in Dubai for the annual climate summit.

clips.episodeTitle: Former U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger dies aged 100
clips.synopsis: Kissinger dominated foreign policy as the United States exited Vietnam and broke down barriers with China, earning both criticism and praise.

clips.episodeTitle: Floods subside in Brechin but anger remains as clean-up continues weeks later
clips.synopsis: Six weeks on from Storm Babet, the people of Brechin feel that more needs to be done to help with the clean-up and stop a repeat of the disastrous flooding.

clips.episodeTitle: Grandfather from Gaza speaks of grief at the death of his two young grandchildren
clips.synopsis: The lull in the fighting between Israel and Hamas has allowed one grief-stricken grandfather in Gaza to return to the ruins of his family home.

clips.episodeTitle: Shoplifting surge: Retail staff paying the price as policing minister encourages citizen's arrests
clips.synopsis: As part of a shoplifting investigation, ITV News has spoken to retail workers who have fallen victim to aggression and violence at the hands of thieves.

clips.episodeTitle: ITV News told vaping addiction rising with five million people using them daily
clips.synopsis: A new survey estimates a quarter of all British adults have tried vapes, with women and older generations puffing more frequently than others.

clips.episodeTitle: Cystic fibrosis drug will no longer be recommended to children due to high cost
clips.synopsis: NICE say the price of drugs like Kaftrio, which can cost up to £184,000 but can extend lives by 30 years, is too expensive for the NHS.

clips.episodeTitle: IDF shows ITV News inside Gaza's tunnels at Al-Shifa hospital complex
clips.synopsis: ITV News was taken by the IDF into the heart of Gaza City to look inside the main Al-Shifa hospital complex, where thousands of people had been sheltering.

clips.episodeTitle: Doctors warn of dangerous impact of measles as cases spike and vaccine uptake slumps
clips.synopsis: Public health officials have told ITV News every region in England has reported an infection, which could lead to fatal consequences.

clips.episodeTitle: New coming of age film explores themes of consent and sex
clips.synopsis: 'How to Have Sex' director Molly Manning Walker says she hopes her film will help students discuss issues around consent openly.

clips.episodeTitle: Firefighters suffered racism that drove them to take their own lives, families tell ITV News
clips.synopsis: Relatives of firefighters who they say lost their lives to racism have told our UK Editor Paul Brand they want urgent change within the service.

clips.episodeTitle: Young lives cut short in Gaza's 'graveyard for children' as over 5,000 feared dead
clips.synopsis: ITV News hears stories of loss and fear from the Gaza Strip, where over 5,000 children are feared to have died since the onset of the conflict in the region.

clips.episodeTitle: 'No fault evictions' rise by 38% in a year as government delays court order ban
clips.synopsis: ITV News meets victims of what's known as a "Section 21 notice", a court order which is used by landlords in England to evict their tenants with no explanation.

clips.episodeTitle: ITV News enters Gaza for first time and witnesses devastation from weeks of bombing
clips.synopsis: The team was escorted into the town of Beit Hanoun in northern Gaza by Israeli forces, who supervised what they were allowed to film and to show.

clips.episodeTitle: Whistleblowing: Are NHS doctors being listened to when they raise concerns?
clips.synopsis: A survey, carried out for ITV by the hospital doctors' union HCSA, found more than 70% think it would damage their careers to speak up about patient safety.

clips.episodeTitle: What are the big questions Boris Johnson is facing at the Covid Inquiry?
clips.synopsis: The former Prime Minister faces two days of examination, where his handling of the pandemic and the workings of his government will come under the spotlight.

clips.episodeTitle: Do you have rizz? Oxford University Press unveils word of the year for 2023
clips.synopsis: Rizz was chosen after Spiderman actor Tom Holland used it in an interview. The word is often used to describe someone's ability to attract a potential partner.

clips.episodeTitle: COP28: Are the climate summits achieving what they set out to?
clips.synopsis: World leaders are flying to Dubai for the annual conference, but there is controversy over the host nation's impartiality.

clips.episodeTitle: Is climate change disproportionately affecting amateur sports?
clips.synopsis: The British Association of Sustainable Sport is calling for better data collection and more funding to help clubs adapt to the changing climate.

clips.episodeTitle: What does the Autumn Statement mean for you and will it shift the political dial?
clips.synopsis: We take a look at the key measures announced, what they mean for households across the country and whether they'll boost the Tories electoral chances.

clips.episodeTitle: Why is Qatar so involved in hostage deal negotiations and what's in it for them?
clips.synopsis: Qatar isn't a big country, but it's an increasingly powerful one on the world stage and has played a key role in hostage negotiations between Israel and Hamas.

clips.episodeTitle: Parcel firms delivering a 'miserable' service to customers, say Citizens Advice
clips.synopsis: Find out where the country's major delivery firms rank in the Citizens Advice league table.

clips.episodeTitle: Breakthrough gene therapy offers hope for people with two blood disorders
clips.synopsis: The treatment could be used for people with sickle cell disease and beta thalassemia. It works by correcting a genetic error relating to red blood cells.

clips.episodeTitle: Is Rishi Sunak on track to meet his five pledges to the public?
clips.synopsis: Back in January, the Prime Minister made five key promises to voters which he said people should judge him on. So what progress has he made on them?

clips.episodeTitle: Supreme Court to determine the fate of the government's Rwanda migrant plan
clips.synopsis: On Wednesday, the UK's highest court will give its ruling on whether the government's plan to send some of those arriving on small boats to Rwanda can go ahead.

clips.episodeTitle: Home Secretary Suella Braverman's most controversial moments
clips.synopsis: After causing yet another row with her article about 'bias' in the policing of protests, we look at some of the Home Secretary's most controversial moments.

clips.episodeTitle: How will children be protected online under new laws?
clips.synopsis: New regulations put forward by Ofcom will require the biggest social media sites to protect children from online groomers.

clips.episodeTitle: Rising from the ashes: Destroyed Derby school rebuilt to be the most eco-friendly in England
clips.synopsis: Following an arson attack three years ago, pupils and staff at St Mary's Catholic Voluntary Academy have had their first day at their new eco-friendly school.

clips.episodeTitle: The Northern Ireland pub that has got everyone talking with their Christmas advert
clips.synopsis: Charlie's Bar in Enniskillen, County Fermanagh, posted a video on Saturday and it has already racked up millions of views on social media.

clips.episodeTitle: Cliff collapse in Suffolk reveals unexploded bomb
clips.synopsis: A controlled explosion has been carried out on a suspected bomb found at the base of a cliff which collapsed earlier today.

clips.episodeTitle: Mayor blocks move to build huge Vegas-style Sphere in London - but are plans completely deflated?
clips.synopsis: The Mayor of London said the LED light-filled venue would have a negative impact on local residents which outweighed potential economic benefits.

clips.episodeTitle: What's next for the 17-year-old named Britain's top female surfer?
clips.synopsis: A 17-year-old from Newquay has been named Britain's top female surfer and is looking ahead to competing at the Olympics while studying for her A Levels

clips.episodeTitle: Last chance to see UK's only giant pandas before they leave Edinburgh Zoo
clips.synopsis: Tian Tian and Yang Guang will return to China in December after 12 years in Scotland, leaving visitors only two weeks to see them.

clips.episodeTitle: Celebrating the legacy of Windrush and breaking down barriers through jewellery
clips.synopsis: Norma Banton's was the first black woman to open a shop in the heart of Birmingham's jewellry quarter, where she's working to keep her parent's legacy alive.

clips.episodeTitle: The million pound plan to save the UK's Pine Martens
clips.synopsis: Pine Martens have become virtually extinct in England, but new plans in Northumberland hope to restore their habitats.

clips.episodeTitle: Supermarket chain Booths ditches self-checkouts in customer service drive
clips.synopsis: Supermarket chain Booths is scrapping 'problematic' and 'unreliable' self-service checkouts in an effort to 'double down' on its customer service standards.

clips.episodeTitle: Music icon Sting receives Freedom of the Borough of North Tyneside
clips.synopsis: Multi-award-winning musician Sting has received the Freedom of the Borough of North Tyneside, the highest honour any local authority can bestow.

clips.episodeTitle: Shear brilliance: How Welsh wool could help prevent peat bogs from drying out
clips.synopsis: A new trial is underway in the Brecon Beacons, using thick fleeces of Welsh sheep to stem the erosive flow of water of vital peat bogs.

clips.episodeTitle: Thousands of baby lobsters released into the sea in a bid to save the North East's fishing industry
clips.synopsis: Whitby's status as one of the largest lobster-catching ports in Europe has been under threat due to declining fishing stocks.

clips.episodeTitle: Young girl meets the stem donor who saved her life
clips.synopsis: Sofia Gardella was diagnosed with a rare blood disorder aged two. In 2015 Sofia was matched with a woman from Germany, whose stem cells saved her life.

longformData.description: Follow King Charles’ state visit to Kenya in this special programme

longformData.title: Ukraine's Stolen Children
longformData.description: Compelling story of the children taken to Russia after war broke out
